auto_merge.commit_message:
Essentially, in a lot of cases a refcount of 1 tells us that no other
thread has access to a variable and thus we can directly use the fast
macro indexing. A micro-benchmark suggests this is twice as fast where
it hits, and also that it doesn't cause much measureable difference
where it misses.

Microbenchmark:

```
# cython: freethreading_compatible = True

cimport cython

@cython.boundscheck(False)
def run(miss):
    cdef list l1, l2
    cdef int i, size1, size2
    l1, l2 = make_lists()
    if miss:
        tmp = [l1, l2]
    size1 = len(l1)
    size2 = len(l2)
    for i in range(10000):
        l1[i % size1] = l2[i % size2]

def make_lists():
    return [i for i in range(50)], [i for i in range(27)]

from timeit import timeit

print(timeit("run(False)", globals=globals(), number=1000))
print(timeit("run(True)", globals=globals(), number=1000))
```

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Essentially, in a lot of cases a refcount of 1 tells us that no other thread has access to a variable and thus we can directly use the fast macro indexing. A micro-benchmark suggests this is twice as fast where it hits, and also that it doesn't cause much measureable difference where it misses.

Microbenchmark:

```
# cython: freethreading_compatible = True

cimport cython

@cython.boundscheck(False)
def run(miss):
    cdef list l1, l2
    cdef int i, size1, size2
    l1, l2 = make_lists()
    if miss:
        tmp = [l1, l2]
    size1 = len(l1)
    size2 = len(l2)
    for i in range(10000):
        l1[i % size1] = l2[i % size2]

def make_lists():
    return [i for i in range(50)], [i for i in range(27)]

from timeit import timeit

print(timeit("run(False)", globals=globals(), number=1000))
print(timeit("run(True)", globals=globals(), number=1000))
```

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1066,6 +1066,14 @@ static CYTHON_INLINE PyObject * __Pyx_PyDict_GetItemStrWithError(PyObject *dict,
   #define __Pyx_PyList_GetItemRef(o, i) __Pyx_NewRef(PyList_GET_ITEM(o, i))
 #endif
 
+
+#if CYTHON_AVOID_THREAD_UNSAFE_BORROWED_REFS && !CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_LIMITED_API && CYTHON_ASSUME_SAFE_MACROS
+  #define __Pyx_PyList_GetItemRefFast(o, i, unsafe_shared) ((unsafe_shared || Py_REFCNT(o) > 1) ? \

comment_data.body: This is specifically guarded by `CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_CPYTHON_FREETHREADING` because I'm worried that `Py_REFCNT` will be opaque in the Limited API so might not get skipped, even if the critical section block is obvious a no-op

Another obvious candidate for this method is `CoerceToPyTypeNode` because it always returns a freshly created object that cannot be shared (except for constants like `True` etc.). That might not be all that relevant for the use case of list item access (ignoring unlikely cases like `std::vector` coercion) but if we introduce the concept of thread-safely owned objects then we can consider that node a safe hint.

That suggests that the safety status is not boolean but rather: unknown, definitely unsafe, definitely safe. Not sure if knowing this would make a difference at runtime, I guess only measurements could tell.

   #define __Pyx_SET_SIZE(obj, size) Py_SIZE(obj) = (size)
 #endif
 
+#if CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_CPYTHON || CYTHON_COMPILING_IN_LIMITED_API
+#define __Pyx_REFCNT_MAY_BE_SHARED(o) Py_REFCNT(o) > 1

comment_data.body: By editing accident or by intention? Why is one better than the other?

You can avoid the `bool()` calls below.
```suggestion
    bint unsafe_shared_set
```

@@ -0,0 +1,105 @@
+# mode: run
+
+# This test abuses the cname feature to modify the utility code so we can find out
+# if the indexing functions are being called with unsafe_shared set.
+# Then it checks if that matches our expectations.
+
+# Don't worry about actually compiling with OpenMP though.
+from cython.parallel cimport prange
+
+# Intercept list indexing calls and record whether "unsafe_shared" was set
+cdef extern from *:
+    """
+    static int unsafe_shared_set;
+
+    static PyObject *__Pyx_GetItemInt_List_Fast(PyObject *o, Py_ssize_t i,
+                                                int wraparound, int boundscheck, int unsafe_shared);
+    static PyObject *Call_GetItemInt_List_Fast(PyObject *o, Py_ssize_t i,
+                                                int wraparound, int boundscheck, int unsafe_shared) {
+        unsafe_shared_set = unsafe_shared;
+        return __Pyx_GetItemInt_List_Fast(o, i, wraparound, boundscheck, unsafe_shared);
+    }
+
+    #define do_nothing()
+    """
+    int unsafe_shared_set

@@ -0,0 +1,105 @@
+# mode: run
+
+# This test abuses the cname feature to modify the utility code so we can find out
+# if the indexing functions are being called with unsafe_shared set.
+# Then it checks if that matches our expectations.
+
+# Don't worry about actually compiling with OpenMP though.
+from cython.parallel cimport prange
+
+# Intercept list indexing calls and record whether "unsafe_shared" was set
+cdef extern from *:
+    """
+    static int unsafe_shared_set;
+
+    static PyObject *__Pyx_GetItemInt_List_Fast(PyObject *o, Py_ssize_t i,
+                                                int wraparound, int boundscheck, int unsafe_shared);
+    static PyObject *Call_GetItemInt_List_Fast(PyObject *o, Py_ssize_t i,
+                                                int wraparound, int boundscheck, int unsafe_shared) {
+        unsafe_shared_set = unsafe_shared;
+        return __Pyx_GetItemInt_List_Fast(o, i, wraparound, boundscheck, unsafe_shared);
+    }
+
+    #define do_nothing()
+    """
+    int unsafe_shared_set
+    void undef_getitemint_list_fast "#undef __Pyx_GetItemInt_List_Fast \n do_nothing" ()
+    void define_new_getitemint_list_fast "#define __Pyx_GetItemInt_List_Fast(o, i, wraparound, boundscheck, unsafe_shared) Call_GetItemInt_List_Fast(o, i, wraparound, boundscheck, unsafe_shared) \n do_nothing" ()
+
+
+def dummy_func():
+    # abuse cname feature to redefine __Pyx_GetItemInt_List_Fast so that we can intercept the call
+    define_new_getitemint_list_fast()
+
+def local_var():
+    """
+    >>> local_var()
+    False
+    """
+    global unsafe_shared_set
+    unsafe_shared_set = False
+    cdef list l = [None]
+    x = l[0]
+    return bool(unsafe_shared_set)
+
+def closure1():
+    """
+    >>> closure1()
+    True
+    """
+    global unsafe_shared_set
+    unsafe_shared_set = False
+    l = [None]
+
+    def function_that_captures_l():
+        return l
+    x = l[0]
+    return bool(unsafe_shared_set)
+
+def closure2():
+    """
+    >>> closure2()
+    True
+    """
+    global unsafe_shared_set
+    unsafe_shared_set = False
+    l = [None]
+
+    def function_that_captures_l():
+        return l[0]
+    x = function_that_captures_l()
+    return bool(unsafe_shared_set)
+
+cdef class ListAttr:
+    cdef list l
+    def __init__(self):
+        self.l = [None]
+
+    def test_list_attr(self):
+        """
+        >>> ListAttr().test_list_attr()
+        True
+        """
+        global unsafe_shared_set
+        unsafe_shared_set = False
+        x = self.l[0]
+        return bool(unsafe_shared_set)
+
+
+def in_prange():
+    """
+    >>> in_prange()
+    True
+    """
+    global unsafe_shared_set
+    unsafe_shared_set = False
+    l = [None]
+    for i in prange(1, nogil=True):
+        with gil:
+            x = l[0]
+    return bool(unsafe_shared_set)
+
+
+def dummy_func2():
+    # abuse cname feature to undefine our override to allow the utility code to be generated
+    undef_getitemint_list_fast()

comment_data.body: Accident - an earlier revision had the logic in this line

`CoerceToPyTypeNode` should be covered by `is_temp`.

> That suggests that the safety status is not boolean but rather: unknown, definitely unsafe, definitely safe. Not sure if knowing this would make a difference at runtime, I guess only measurements could tell.

Yes true. We definitely apply that idea "manually" (e.g. we always use `PyList_SET_ITEM` in list comprehensions).

> I guess only measurements could tell.

A quick test suggests a 25% speed-up from skipping the refcount check completely.

> because it always returns a freshly created object that cannot be shared

I don't think that's absolutely true unfortunately. Coercing a typed memoryview to a Python-type can return an existing object I think. I don't think that would be affected by anything in this PR but it suggests we shouldn't be treating `CoerceToPyTypeNode` as a definitely fresh object.

------------------------------------------------------

So I agree "definitely unshared" is a worthwhile optimization but I don't see too many easy uses right now.

commit.message:
Shortcut some freethreading indexing

Essentially, in a lot of cases a refcount of 1 tells us that
no other thread has access to a variable and thus we can
directly use the fast macro indexing. A micro-benchmark
suggests this is twice as fast where it hits, and also
that it doesn't cause much measureable difference where it
misses.

milestone.description: First feature release after the cleanup releases 3.0 and 3.1.

title: Shortcut some freethreading indexing
